TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON RăzvanHoraţiu PERSON , of ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . NORP In an action before ORG , the applicant claimed CARDINAL ( ORG ) in damages from an international road transport company ( “ the company ” ) , alleging that it had failed to perform its contractual obligations .

CARDINAL . He claimed that in respect of a return journey between GPE and GPE , which had cost him ORG CARDINAL , the company had failed to observe the safety and comfort requirements set out in its advertising material , namely the provision of fully reclining seats , a change of coach in GPE and the availability of CARDINAL drivers .
CARDINAL . On DATE he requested the production of the relevant transport documents held by the defendant company .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE the court dismissed his action . After examining the clauses of the contract of carriage , it found that none of the conditions referred to by the applicant were mentioned . The court did not rule on the request for the production of certain items of evidence .

CARDINAL . NORP In an appeal on points of law received in the court 's registry on DATE , the applicant challenged that judgment . In his grounds of appeal , filed in the registry on DATE , he alleged that the impugned judgment was based on contradictory grounds , that it was the result of an erroneous application of the law and that it infringed the law . The applicant added that the court had failed to rule on certain defences that were crucial for the outcome of the dispute and that it had misinterpreted the subject - matter of the proceedings .
CARDINAL . He developed his arguments relying on provisions of LAW and on the interpretation of the contractual clauses .

CARDINAL . The case was referred to ORG and Justice ( “ the High Court ” ) . Under LAW as then in force , the appeal was subject to a CARDINAL - stage examination : first , ORG would adjudicate in private on its admissibility and , if it was declared admissible , the merits of the impugned judgment would then be examined in a public hearing .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted “ pleadings concerning the admissibility of the appeal ” in which he argued that it should be declared admissible because the substantive and procedural conditions were satisfied .

CARDINAL . In a final judgment delivered in private on DATE in the absence of the parties , who had not been summoned to appear , ORG declared the appeal null and void , under Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure as then in force , on the ground that it had not stated the reasons why ORG decision was alleged to be unlawful .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied to have that judgment set aside , alleging that it was the result of a manifest error on the part of ORG , because he had set out his grounds of appeal in the document filed on DATE . In addition , he complained about the lack of publicity of the proceedings before ORG .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG rejected his application on the ground that no appeal lay against the judgment of DATE .
CARDINAL . The Code of Civil Procedure ( as amended by ORG no . CARDINAL of DATE ) , as worded at the material time , contained the following provisions :
“ Appeals on points of law shall be heard by ORG and ORG , unless otherwise provided by law . ”
“ Statements of appeal on points of law shall , if they are not to be declared null and void , ... indicate the grounds of illegality raised and contain the corresponding reasoning ... ”
“ The setting - aside or quashing of a judgment may be sought only in the following cases and for the following reasons :
CARDINAL . NORP if the bench was composed in breach of the statutory provisions ;
CARDINAL . NORP if the judgment was delivered by judges other than those who heard the case on the merits ;
CARDINAL . NORP if the judgment was rendered in disregard of the jurisdiction of another court ;
CARDINAL . NORP if the court exceeded its jurisdiction ;
CARDINAL . NORP if the judgment was rendered contrary to rules of procedure of which a breach carries the sanction of nullity ... ;
CARDINAL . NORP if the judgment was rendered ultra petita ;
CARDINAL . NORP if the judgment did not give reasons or if it was based on reasoning that was contradictory or unrelated to the subject - matter of the proceedings ;
CARDINAL . NORP if , on account of misinterpretation , the court modified the subject - matter of the proceedings whereas that subject - matter had been clear and undisputed ;
CARDINAL . NORP if the judgment was not based on the law , if it infringed the law , or if it was the result of an erroneous application of the law ;
CARDINAL . if the court failed to rule on certain defences or certain documents in the file that were crucial for the outcome of the dispute . ”

“ An appeal on points of law against a judgment which is not subject to an ordinary appeal shall not be limited to the situations provided for in LAW , as the appellate court shall be entitled to examine all the aspects of the case . ”
“ The president of the court which receives the appeal on points of law shall appoint a bench of CARDINAL judges to rule on its admissibility ...

If the judges are unanimous in finding that the admissibility conditions are not satisfied , or if they find that the grounds of appeal and the accompanying arguments do not correspond to those set out in LAW , they shall declare the appeal null and void or , if appropriate , reject it in a reasoned decision without summoning the parties , that decision not being subject to appeal . ”

CARDINAL . Law no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE , further amending LAW , repealed the provisions of Emergency Order no . CARDINAL concerning the exclusive jurisdiction of ORG and ORG to hear appeals on points of law , together with the provisions concerning the preliminary examination of their admissibility . Appeals on points of law are now examined by the courts that are immediately above those that gave the judgments at first instance or on appeal , without any preliminary examination of admissibility , and in accordance with the ordinary procedure provided for by LAW .
